ResponsesInList.Title: How do I add questions to a game?
ResponsesInList.Text: I have just installed the Game plug in, and cannot figure out how to add questions. I've been playing with crossword - and when I go to add questions I end up in the question bank, but can find no way to add the selected questions to the game. What am I missing?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How do I add questions to a game?
ResponsesInList.Text: It sounds like you're trying to add questions to a crossword puzzle, but you're getting stuck in the question bank and not being able to add them to the game. Let me guide you through the process: Create or open a crossword puzzle : Make sure you're in the crossword section and have either started a new puzzle or opened an existing one. Access the question bank : In the crossword editor, there‚Äôs typically an option to view or manage the question bank. This is where your stored questions live. Select questions from the question bank : Once you're in the question bank, look for a way to either choose or add questions to your current game. Depending on the plugin, this might involve selecting individual questions or importing them into the puzzle. Add questions to the crossword : There should be a button or option to add the selected question to the grid. This might be labeled something like "Add to Puzzle," "Insert into Grid," or simply ‚ÄúUse in Game.‚Äù Review the crossword grid : After adding your questions, check that the clues and answers are showing up correctly in the grid, adjusting if necessary. Save and play : Once you‚Äôve added all your questions and clues, save your puzzle and start playing! If you're not seeing an option to add questions to the grid, it might be a specific feature or setting of the plugin you're using. It might help to check the plugin‚Äôs documentation or reach out to the support team for more detailed instructions. Regards, ovaroms.com

Each Avatar moves up or down their side in response to the answer to a player selected question, selected from pre-existing possibilities. Ideally the player would be able to select which Avatar they wish to play as. An example of how this could be used would Avatar 1 would be Aircraft Passenger, Avatar 2 would be Cabin Crew If the ladder is showing how to maintain calmness in a aircraft Avatar 1 question can I have a drink please. Avatar 2 responses a/ Yes certainly b/ NO! If the player selected b then the Avatar 1 and 2 would move up their sides of the ladder towards disruption at the top. If the player selected a then they would both stay where they were. the next question would again move them up or down the ladder as a result of their response. Does anyone have any suggestions of a plugin that would allow this? Regards Paul

ResponsesInList.Title: GAME BOOK
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I haven't been able to get the game/book to play. Is there documentation to show how to link the game/book to a book from which quetions are drawn? Thank you, Alex

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: GAME BOOK
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Alex, Do you mean the Activites/Games plugin found here: https://moodle.org/plugins/mod_game ? If so, the questions are drawn from a Book Resource that you create beforehand. So the general steps are: In the course where you want to use the Game-Book activity, Add a Book Resource and create several chapters. Each chapter title will be a question heading in the Game-Book quiz and the chapter content will be the content of the "question" After you have saved the Book, go to Add an activity or resource, ¬†then choose Games, Book with questions The page should then look something like that shown below with the select a book drop-down already selecting the Book you just created. Fill in the rest of the options and Save. It should now work If you run into Error 500 - Internal File Server errors you'll have to fix these on your server. I've found that if you follow the steps here , that should fix the error. Apparently this is a Moodle system bug that was re-introduced in version 3.x and is slated for fixing in a new release. Hope this helps cheers, Derek

It worked, except now I'm not clear how to generate the questions? ¬†I see the chapter titles right to the left of ¬†the book as you can see in the screenshop. I was expecting questions to be generated that the students will have to answer/quizzed on and their grade will go into their gradebook. Is this not the case? Thank you, Alex

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Replacing the Images in Hangman
ResponsesInList.Text: Just out of curiosity, I looked at that last week when David originally posed his question, but got interrupted by students before I had a chance to reply. The option 1, appears to be hard coded. It is located in line 213 of mod_form.php which is located at yourmoodle/mod/game/mod_form.pgp. So, you can change pictures a couple of ways. Ask the developers to implement the option, re-write the code yourself to let you actually select a different picture set, replace the set of 7 pictures in folder located....moodle/mod/game/pix/hangman/1 with your own set, add another folder of pictures and change the hard coded 1 to your desired folder. AL

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Replacing the Images in Hangman
ResponsesInList.Text: I had a few minutes between grading sessions, and it is actually very easy to fix hangman so that you can use your own pictures, or the original. Create you own set of 7 pictures in a folder named 2 - I used the same names. Place your new folder at yourmoodle/mod/game/pix/hangman/2 Edit line 213 of ...yourmoodle/mod/game/mod_form.php and change it to $a = array( 1 => 1, 2 => 2); Under Game Administration go to Edit settings>Hangman Options>Select the images of hangman¬† and change it to 2. Try out the game to see your new pictures in use. AL

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Replacing the Images in Hangman
ResponsesInList.Text: Would this edit allow for the use of GIF images instead of JPEGs? Or is that hard coded as well? Would that be an easy fix? Thanks in advance.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Replacing the Images in Hangman
ResponsesInList.Text: I don't know about other picture formats. Should be easy to test. Just make a set of gif's or png's and try them. They will either work or they won't. Turn on developer debugging and it should let you know right away. AL

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Re: Replacing the Images in Hangman
ResponsesInList.Text: Now does not support multiple set of images and images of different type. On the last of May will be available a version that will support it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Game module crossword pulling unwanted questions 1.9.4
ResponsesInList.Text: When you play the game as a teacher there is a tab named "Show answers". There you can see which questions it reads to produce the crossword. Check again the parameters. Maybe it uses a glossary instead of questions. Try the tab "Show attempts" and delete the open attempts.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Game module crossword pulling unwanted questions 1.9.4
ResponsesInList.Text: Today our IT support sat down and dug into this.¬† The game was set to look at the course question bank but the mystery questions were pulling from a glossary in a different course (in a completely different category!).¬† When we looked at other games we found the same problem.¬† We went to the course and there were a couple games.¬†¬† We deleted the games from the course (it isn't currently in use) and all the games everywhere else started working again. The problem is solved but we still don't know why it happened.¬† I have a suspicion that the glossary may have been created with cut/paste from word and the creators may not have cleaned the HTML out.¬† Sometimes the html from word is pretty ugly.¬† The only thing I can think of is that there is something weird in the glossary html that when it got pulled into a game it freaked out the whole module.¬† I have no idea what sort of HTML could do that but it's the only idea I have.¬† I'm thinking of cleaning up their glossary (apparently I'm an on-line maid) but haven't gotten the chance.

ResponsesInList.Title: No group support?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, We have been testing this module for a while and it looks great, but we really need group support as we want to use it to practice vocabulary in courses where students use different vocabulary books/glossaries. I.e. we want to make one game based on vocabulary from glossary A and another game based on vocabulary from glossary B. Does this module not support groups? I have not found any setting for it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: No group support?
ResponsesInList.Text: Now does not support groups. Tell¬† me more details how imagine this and how will be the parameters. May be I do it in the future.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: No group support?
ResponsesInList.Text: If I can put my 2 cents worth in as well. I would like to extend the concept of groups to include multiple intelligence. When a student enters a course they are placed in a group.¬† For the purpose of the games module they will all see the same glossary.¬†¬† However students in group A would like to work with a specific category of the glossary while other groups have there own categories.¬† All in the same course.¬†¬† It would also be very useful if when a student from category A reaches a level of competency they are automatically moved up to a higher level of challenge. The games module is a credit to you and I congratulate you on your exceptional efforts. John

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: No group support?
ResponsesInList.Text: I am not sure what you mean by your question. I am not a developer, so I do not know if there are many ways to do this/different parameters for it. I thought there is a standard way to implement group support: Almost all the core modules and many contributed modules support groups, so that if a module ( both Content or Activity ) is added to a course that has groups and groupings, you can define access and/or visibility for the module in the interface for editing the module. If your module supported groups (and, by the way, support for Grade category would also be great!), there would be a section under editing the module (the interface where you choose what game to use, where questions are taken from, game specific settings, etc.) called " Common module settings " It would have boxes and choices Group mode Grouping Available for group members only Visible ID number Grade category As far as I know (and the title for the section is Common module settings, after all) this is standard interface/parameters for modules. If you look at the Edit/Settings page of any core activity, for example a Quiz, you will see what I mean (you may have to click the "Show advanced" button to see all the options I listed above). I hope you will implement this, as it is a standard feature for Moodle modules and one that we rely heavily on, as I mentioned in my original post. We really love these games, so it would be a shame if we can't use them! Best, T

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: No group support?
ResponsesInList.Text: I re-read this thread, and I wonder if you misunderstood me when asking about more details. I did not mean for the module to be able to pull in different kinds of glossaries based on group membership, for example having only one instance of Games pull words from Glossary A when a member of the A group uses it and from Glossary B when a member of the B group uses it. That would be great, come to think of it, but I would happily make two instances of the Games module, just as I do now with Quizzes: Hangman for Vocabulary A (the Game module set to use Hangman and set to only be visible to group A in the course) Hangman for Vocabulary B (the Game module set to use Hangman and set to only be visible to group B in the course)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: No group support?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Value to Millionaire Questions

ResponsesInList.Title: BUG FIX - glossary term links breaks Answer button on Cryptex
ResponsesInList.Text: I've just had to fix something on the latest build of Game in the Cryptex puzzle type. Basically if you have a glossary item that has links to other glossary items in it, it breaks the ability to answer that question. SO I've added a line after it renders out the question number and text that runs strip_tags before the question text gets posted into the answer the question box: line 236 (on my copy): echo "$i. ".$question; line 237 (on my copy): $question = strip_tags($question); //ADDED BY DP (AUG 2009) - fixes " breaking the Answer button for this question Hope that helps some of you as it was driving the tutor who told me about mad! Dave

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: BUG FIX - glossary term links breaks Answer button on Cryptex
ResponsesInList.Text: In addition, I found that if an apostrophe is in the definition of the glossary item then that breaks the button also! So an escape character is needed. New line: line 238 (on my copy): $question = str_replace("'","\'",$question);

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Re: BUG FIX - glossary term links breaks Answer button on Cryptex
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you David. I included your fix to the source. If you have another fix or improvement, it will be welcome.

ResponsesInList.Title: Snakes and Ladders won't work with MS SQL
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Has anyone else had problems getting the snakes and ladders game working with MS SQL 2005? It appears to be related to the use of a reserved word in the "games_snakes_database" table.¬† The word "file" is a reserved word in MS SQL, and as such it creates the field as [file].¬† In turn this stops SQL scripts from completing. Cheers Mark

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Snakes and Ladders won't work with MS SQL
ResponsesInList.Text: I changed the name of field "file" to "fileboard".

ResponsesInList.Title: Better instructions?
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm a big proponent of games-based learning, and have been trying to figure out how to build them in moodle 1.9, but only instructions I can find very vague and limited to ""you'll have to create different kinds of questions for different games" (What kind of questions go with what kind of games? What question type do I use as a "simple answer" question - there is not an option for "simple answer" in the Quiz/Question module; What kind of multiple choice questions "work" with millionaire? MCMA? MCSA?) and "use the edit button to change the games." After several frustrating hours of trying to figure things out with very limited instructions, I still can't get the crossword puzzle to generate more than 2 columns (regardless of how I set the parameters) I can't figure out how to set up snakes & ladders, hangman gives me incorrect answers (even though the responses in the source questions are correct) and only allows me to create 1 question per game (even though I set the parameters for more than one) and millionaire works sporadically, if at all. Can someone please direct me to better step-by-step instructions? Thanks!

ResponsesInList.Title: Game Theory Module Please
ResponsesInList.Text: A game theory module, that allowed a teacher to set parameters for cooperation and non-cooperation, and¬†parameters governing how players gain trust points perhpas: An example of a user vs computer game http://people.hofstra.edu/faculty/Stefan_Waner/gametheory/games.html A list of online game theory software http://www.econport.org/econport/request?page=web_or_list&categoryID=2 User vs User volunteers dilemma http://veconlab.econ.virginia.edu/vd/vd.htm Tim

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Game Theory Module Please
ResponsesInList.Text: > A game theory module, that allowed a teacher to set parameters for > cooperation and non-cooperation, and parameters governing how players > gain trust points You mean that you would like some kind of module that would allow a teacher creating a course about game theory to create a game that they could slot into their course and direct students to play. Sounds do-able - an activity module is probably what you would need.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Game Theory Module Please
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear David Hicks, Thank you for your response. The game you reference is vs the computer. I would like to have students play each other, but propbably not live - asynchonously. There are some others online though it seems. I was thinking of using university students¬†but perhaps even giving small cash prizes! The initial impetus for wanting this sort of functionality is because games are used in cultural psychology e.g. in the work of Yoshio Yamagishi http://www.istc.cnr.it/T3/map/cells/env-soc.html He finds that Japanese and Americans play games similarly until the strategies of other players is a secret. Then Japanese play more un-altruistically, due to lower levels of generalised trust, he argues. I thought that the protection vs. promotion mechanism¬†"nickel" experiment here http://www.psych.ubc.ca/~ara/Psych407/Takeshi_april3.pdf might work well in a game theory¬†paradigm, using instead of nickels, some sort of display of trust, like the points at ebay. It would be predicted that Americans would be motivated to increase (promote)¬†their "trust points", but that Japanese would be more motivate not to allow their trust points to decrease (protection). As well as just a game with payoffs, I would really want some way of displaying a players past behaviour. But it sounds like it would cost about 3000 dollars to program. And I already have one experimental psychology module, the TUI to keep up. Tim

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Game Theory Module Please
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Guys, I'm interested in a Game theory Module too. In fact, I'm already developing one (just making the databases conection). But I think it's a great deal to do it. I'm have a Master Degree in Applied Math and I wish I could make my students to play against each other (asynchronously or not) too. Do you like to participate? david, I send you and e-mail. Reply me. BR, Rafael Luiz Rafael dos Santos, Msc FURB - Regional University of Blumenau Brazil

ResponsesInList.Title: Hangman
ResponsesInList.Text: At the college we often use hangman style games to reinforce vocabulary etc. I have produced a version using php running off a text file but given the demand for the tool and that lecturers want to assemble their own word/clue lists on the fly with students I am intending to port to a mySQL backend. Part of the problem is that access to the word-lists needs to be restricted (for obvious reasons) and I though about linking into Moodle authentication as the staff already have accounts set up. When a member of staff accesses a restricted page I want to redirect them to the Moodle login and then if they are authenticated pass them back to the secure page. Trouble is I don't understand how to do this :o( I have examined the mdl_user table and can see that the passwords are encrypted a la Unix. but this is as far as my knowledge goes. Can anyone help or is this something best left well alone...

ResponsesInList.Title: Re:  New activity module: game - version 1.3.2a
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Vasilis, I have been following the discussions regarding your new module with interest as I am in the process of launching a new Moodle site and your module has a lot to offer. I remember a discussion regarding the "hang man" game and the suggestion that there may be a better metaphor to use than a hanging, this set me thinking. Rather than revealing something on an incorrect answer how about revealing something as a reward for a correct answer? Imagine being able to upload an image which the software was able to cover with number of tessalating shapes, e.g. squares. On giving a correct answer one square of the picture would be revealed. This could offer a number of challenges e.g. Can you reveal the whole picture from a limited set of questions? In other words you would only be allowed a maximum number of wrong answers before the whole picture could not be revealed as you would not have enough questions left. Reveal the picture in the minimum number of questions - optimum score would be to get no wrong answers, but there would be enough questions for you eventually to reveal the picture. Answer a question related to the picture in the minimum number of questions e.g. put a name to the face of a famous person or place. You don't need to reveal the whole picture, just enough to enable you to answer the identity. This would require a set of questions to control the revealing of the squares and an additional picture related question. Answer a question related to the picture where there is one question for each square of the picture, plus the picture related question. Which square to reveal could be either sequential or random or dependent on the question answered, as¬†appropriate to the game type. I have not had the opportunity to run your module yet, so if this facility already exists then please ignore this posting. Kind regards Johnathan

ResponsesInList.Title: Re:  New activity module: game - version 1.3.2a
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Johnathan, I like your idea. This looks like my sudoku. In sudoku if you answer correct a question you get as a gift the correct number of a cell. As many questtion you answer correct as many numbers you get and the sudoku becomes easier to solve. This is a new game. Maybe the name of this will be "hidden picture" Input: (a) A category of questions or a glossary or a category of a glossary. Each question or glossaryentry will has one picture. (b) A second category of questions or a glossary of a category of a glossary The maximum number of questions for (b) What will do: Will select one question or glossary entry. Will parse the html of that question and will remove the picture Will show the question or glossary entry without the picture Will split the picture to squares and display initially no squares. Will show some question (the maximum numbers selected randomly) For every correct answer will display one square of picture If the user want will have the ability to answer the main question (this about picture) Score: If the user find the answer of main answer 100 % Otherwise (Correct Answers) / (Number of questions) So you get the maximum score if you answer correct the main question or all the other questions. What you think about it ? How will convert your other ideas to include the score? Kind Regards Vasilis

ResponsesInList.Title: Re:  New activity module: game - version 1.3.2a
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Vasilis, I'm glad you liked the picture game idea. Your percentage approach sounds good for scoring There are a number of¬†alternative ways the scoring might be handled, that come to mind, to provide variations on the game. 1. Have one question per square, for example have say 25 questions to give a 5 by 5 grid of squares.¬† If you displayed a 5 by 5 grid the player could then select which question to answer based on its position over the picture, so they had some control over which part of the picture was revealed first. The user scores 1 point for each square answered correctly (an incorrect answer leaves that part of the picture covered over) at any time the player can attempt to answer the question related to the whole picture, at which time they score a bonus of 2 times every question they have not yet attempted to answer. So if someone asked one square question, and got it right and then correctly answered the main picture question they would score 1 for the square question and a further 48 for the remaining 24 questions not attempted. An incorrect guess might be penalised by locking one of the remaining picture squares by removing its related question. Final score would be assigned when all questions had been attempted. In principle the scoring would be x for each correct square question plus 2x for every question that had not been attempted when the picture was correctly guessed. So that would give an absolute score rather than a percentage. 2. Scoring¬†for another game could be for a game where there are more¬†questions than squares. You start with a score of 0 and score x for every right answer and lose¬†y for every wrong answer.¬†You play until you reveal the whole picture, (revealed automatically if you use up all the questions) and then get asked the question for the whole picture for a bonus score. This way you could weight the game by giving more for a correct answer than you take away for a wrong answer, or even set y to 0 so wrong answers are not penalised. If you are keen to provide answers always as percentages then let me know and I will give the matter some more thought. I hope this helps. Kind regards Johnathan

In every game the teacher will set the maximum grade so by multiplying the percentage and the maximum grade will produce the grade for every attempt. ResponsesInList.Title: Re:  New activity module: game - version 1.3.2a - picture game
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Vasilis, OK I have been giving the whole picture game some thought. There are a number of possible variables that would define a number of different games all on the same basic principle, these would be How many squares will cover a picture? If you answer a question incorrectly can you attempt to reveal the square again and if so do you answer the same question again or a different question? Will there be a question for the¬†large picture that is being revealed by the correct answering of square questions? If you answer the large picture question wrong can you have another try? There is also the issue of whether the scoring system should in some way take in to account incorrect answers, so that particularly in games where many attempts can be made to reveal a square that someone who gets the correct answer the first time receives a higher score than someone who takes several attempts before they are successful in revealing the square. What then is needed is a scoring system that will return a percentage figure that can accomodate all these variations. I have modelled this on a spread sheet and it seems to me to give acceptable results, so can I suggest the following two formulas for scoring, which I believe could be applied to all variants of the game. Definitions: Number of attempts = count of all questions attempted whether answered incorrectly or correctly to include both questions asked to reveal squares and questions asked to identify the big picture. Number of correct answers = count of all correct answers given to questions asked to reveal squares and correct answers given to question asked to reveal the big picture. Remaining squares = The count of squares that have not been revealed at this point in the game. If there is a Big picture question and it has been guessed correctly the score is given by (number of correct¬†answers + remaining squares not exposed) / (Number of¬†attempts + remaining squares to be exposed) If there is no big picture question or there is a big picture question but it has not yet been answered correctly then the score is given by (number of correct¬†answers) / (Number of¬†attempts + remaining squares to be exposed) See what you think. Kind regards Johnathan
